function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The current web page is a checkout form with navigation options to different product categories. It has a detailed cart summary showing a Galaxy A2 Core product. The checkout form is divided into sections for customer, address, and payment information with entries for names and email already filled. The address section has entries for country, street address, city, and state filled. The zip code field in the address section and the payment method in the payment section are yet to be completed. A submit button is available for form submission.","new_testing_goal":"Complete the zip code field in the address section, select a payment method, and submit the checkout form to conduct a full transaction simulation.","explanation":"To proceed, the first step is to fill in the zip code in the address section. This is essential to complete the address information. Following this, a payment method will be selected from the dropdown in the Payment section. The final step will be to submit the form by clicking the 'Submit' button. This thorough process will test the form's functionality end-to-end, from data entry to submission.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r42:","keys":"10001"}}

messages.content: Given a web application, you are tasked with assisting in testing its functionality. The emulate_interaction function takes an interaction as input and emulates it on the web application. The return value of the function is the new, filtered HTML source code of the web application. The source code of previous interactions will be omitted from the input to the assistant.
Here are some examples how the 'emulate_interaction' function should be used.
Please test my website: omitted

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description": "The start page of a web site with multiple calculators for different purposes. There are buttons to navigate to the differet calculators and a button to switch the language of the web site. The current language is English.", "new_testing_goal": "Test the calculator for calculating the area of a circle in multiple languages.", "explanation": "First navigate to the calculator for the area of a circle. Then input a radius and calculate the area. Switch the language of the web site and repeat the process.", "interaction": {"interaction_type": "click", "element_id": "btn-area-circle"}}

messages.content: Please test my website. The goal is to test as many different features as possible to find potential bugs, so make sure to include edge cases. Here is the filtered HTML source code of the web application: 'omitted'.

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The checkout page is currently displayed, broken into sections for Customer, Address, and Payment information. The customer section requires details such as first name (already filled as 'John'), last name, and email. In the address section, inputs for country, street address, city, state, and zip code are expected. The payment section offers a dropdown choice between Invoice, Credit Card, and PayPal. A 'Submit' button is present for completing the checkout process. The navigation menu and an overlay indicating an empty cart can also be navigated.","new_testing_goal":"Fill in the email address in the customer information section, then proceed to fill in the address details in the checkout form.","explanation":"By filling in the rest of the fields in the checkout form, starting with the email address in the customer information section, proceed to fill in each of the required fields in the address section following that. This methodical approach allows for a comprehensive test of the form's functionality, ensuring each input field is responsive and captures data as intended.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r3t:","keys":"john.doe@example.com"}}

function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The webpage is currently displaying a checkout form along with a partially filled cart summary. The checkout form is divided into sections for Customer, Address, and Payment information. The Customer section includes partially filled fields for First Name (John), Last Name (Doe), and Email (john.doe@example.com). The Address section is empty and requires data such as Country, Street Address, City, State, and Zip Code. There's a Payment section that allows selection from Invoice, Credit Card, and PayPal. A Submit button is present for completing the checkout process. Additionally, there's a cart summary showing a Galaxy A2 Core with the total price mentioned.","new_testing_goal":"Complete the Address information on the checkout form, select a payment method, and submit the form to observe the outcome. This will test the functionality of the checkout process, including form submission and handling of user input.","explanation":"Start by entering the Country information in the Address section of the checkout form, followed by the Street Address, City, State, and Zip Code. After completing the Address information, select a payment method from the available options in the Payment section. Finally, click on the Submit button to test the checkout process. This step-by-step approach will help to ensure all parts of the checkout form function properly and that input is appropriately handled.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r3u:","keys":"USA"}}

The Address section has 'Country' filled (USA) but requires more details such as Street Address, City, State, and Zip Code. The Payment section offers a dropdown for selecting a payment method (Invoice, Credit Card, PayPal). A Submit button is present for completing the checkout process. Additionally, there's a cart summary showing a Galaxy A2 Core with the total price mentioned.","new_testing_goal":"Complete the checkout process by filling in the missing address information, selecting a payment method, and submitting the form to assess the website's response to a complete transaction.","explanation":"To accomplish this, first fill in the Street Address in the Address Section. The address section has Country and Street Address filled out, but City, State, and Zip Code are empty. A Payment section offers choices between Invoice, Credit Card, and PayPal, but no selection has been made. A Submit button is present. There's also a cart summary showing a product - Galaxy A2 Core with a price of $688.99 and a button to remove this item. The navigation bar has options to navigate to Home, Galaxy, S10, M Series, and A Series pages.","new_testing_goal":"Complete filling in the checkout form by providing city, state, and zip code details in the address section, select a payment method, and then submit the checkout form. This will test the website's form submission functionality and observe the response to a completed transaction.","explanation":"First, fill in the City field in the address section. function_call.name: emulate_interaction
function_call.arguments: {"page_description":"The website is a dynamic e-commerce platform. The visible parts on the website include a navigation bar with links to Home, Galaxy, S10, M Series, and A Series product categories. A checkout area is populated with customer, address, and payment information sections. The customer's name and email are already filled out, with the address part partially completed (Country: USA, Street Address: 123 Galaxy Way, City: Metropolis). The state and zip code fields in the address section are left empty. The payment section offers options for Invoice, Credit Card, and PayPal, yet no selection has been made. There's also a cart summary showing a Galaxy A2 Core with the price revealed and an active checkout button.","new_testing_goal":"The next step is to complete the state and zip code fields in the address section, select a payment method, and submit the checkout form. This step is crucial for assessing the functionality and responsiveness of the checkout process, particularly how the web application handles form submission.","explanation":"First, fill in the 'State' field in the address section. This action moves us closer to completing all necessary information required for the checkout process. Each field completion gets us one step closer to submitting the form, which will allow for observing the web application's response to a complete transaction.","interaction":{"interaction_type":"send_keys","element_id":":r41:","keys":"Gotham"}}

The user provided the following end instructions: Please test my website. The goal is to test as many different features as possible to find potential bugs, so make sure to include edge cases.

Pursue your self-assigned sub-goal or assign a new one: The next step is to complete the state and zip code fields in the address section, select a payment method, and submit the checkout form. This step is crucial for assessing the functionality and responsiveness of the checkout process, particularly how the web application handles form submission..

Start by describing the website supplied by the function call. Give a short general description first then summarize the main elements on the website. Do not use HTML in your description. Then you may formulate a high level sub-goal to the user's instructions, that should be persued with the next couple of interactions. You should formulate a new sub-goal if the current one has been completed or seems to be unattainable. Give an action plan that explains how the goal should be reached. And finally, describe the interaction to emulate.

Only use the click action with clickable elements. The clickable elements have the following ids: :r3n:, :r0:-home, :r0:-galaxy, :r0:-s10, :r0:-m_series, :r0:-a_series, :r1:, :r2:, :r3o:, :r3p:, :r3q:. Only use the send_keys action with writable elements. The writable elements have the following ids: :r3r:, :r3s:, :r3t:, :r3u:, :r3v:, :r40:, :r41:, :r42:. Only use the clear action with clearable elements. The clearable elements have the following ids: :r3r:, :r3s:, :r3t:, :r3u:, :r3v:, :r40:, :r41:.

functions.name: emulate_interaction
functions.description: Emulates a user interaction with the web application

page_description.description: A short textual description of the state of the web application: What is the current page? What are the main elements on the page? This description should not contain any HTML.

new_testing_goal.description: Assigns a new high level sub-goal that shall be followed in order to complete the users instructions. This goal should take multiple user interactions to complete. The assistant shall try to complete this goal in the next couple of interactions and then assign a new one.

explanation.description: An action plan that explains how the goal should be reached.

interaction_type.description: The type of interaction to emulate

element_id.description: The id of the element to interact with

interaction_type.description: The type of interaction to emulate

element_id.description: The id of the element to interact with

keys.description: the keys to be sent to the input element

anyOf.description: sends keystrokes to an html element

interaction_type.description: The type of interaction to emulate

element_id.description: The id of the element to interact with

anyOf.description: resets the contents of an html element
